instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message:
Seems like this had a bad charger as <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> had a burn mark on the dye.
[ATTACH type="full" alt="1662958868449.png"]60778[/ATTACH]

Replaced <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> with a "new" one I had, still not powering on, then noticed having short on <CAPACITOR>C3108</CAPACITOR> - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL>
[ATTACH type="full" width="375px" alt="1662958970667.png"]60779[/ATTACH]
I replaced <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> twice with reballed ones I pulled from another board. Now is stuck on 5V 0.02A with no heat signature. Not sure what is the best way to test the used <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> I pulled from donor boards apart than short on LDO lines once I solder them.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>B_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>B_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0V - cross-checked on both ports
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>B_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 1.8V
<SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INIT_L</SIGNAL> - 3.41V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.41V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message:
Seems like <RESISTOR>R3205</RESISTOR> was shorting to 0 Ohms. Replaced and still not getting <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>B_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> stuck at 5.2V 0.02A

[ATTACH type="full" width="466px"]60783[/ATTACH]
Diode mode measurements are quite close to these of an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> I use as a donor.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message:
"Seems like <RESISTOR>R3205</RESISTOR> was shorting to 0 Ohms"
I never ever saw a resistor shorted.
Do you still have short on <SIGNAL>UPC_XA_UART_TX</SIGNAL>.
If yes, change <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>.

Be aware, when you find CD32xx chip with burn mark, the board may be trash.
It suppose die chip was melt and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> could affected data lines.
These chips are directly connected with PCH/CPU and SMC.
<CHIP>U2890</CHIP> is also connected with <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message:
No more short on  <SIGNAL>UPC_XA_UART_TX</SIGNAL> after I replaced it with the expected 1M.
I was just reading about some [URL='https://logi.wiki/index.php/CD3215_Bootup_Sequence']CD3215C compatibility issues with <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>[/URL]B and how TBT ROM could be reprogrammed. I do not have B ones in stock. Could this be something causing it?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message:
B version doesn't work in place of C; nor viceversa.

Check <RESISTOR>R3205</RESISTOR> value in similar board.
Some Apple schematics show 100K in several resistors from USB-C areas and you will find 0 ohm in real board!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message:
I don't have this exact board for donors, but the two 00840 I have show as 1M.

Perhaps the only option now is to source the B03 version. 00840 and 01041 donors I have are using the C version.

It is a long shot but I do have two TPS65982DA

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message:
The firmware is what import here.
And the end code string specifies firmware version.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message:
Replaced the charging chip with the B version. It worked fine and passed all tests. Left on the shelf, and the customer came to pick it up. Not turning on 😲

Back to the repair bench. I am getting 20V 0.02A. No short circuit on coils, and no heat signature. 

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 13.05V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5.1V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> - 0V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message:
Tried with battery connected?
Check if SMC reset helps.

I suspect bad solders; reflow the area.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message:
Reflowed, it seems to be the same. 20V 0.20A Initially, after a couple of seconds drops and stays at 20V 0.02A board only. 20V 0.5A with battery.
Tried a different case 20V 1.2A seems to be charging. But not turning on

SMC reset didn't work

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message: Was the machine still used with the same charger which damaged it?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message: Oh no, the customer didn't have a chance to pick it up. was staying on the shelf charged.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message: Bad solders, broken traces, internal board damage...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message:
Would we get 20V and these readings if the 3215's are malfunctioning?

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 13.05V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5.1V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> - 0V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message:
USB-C area may be good.
Something else has been affected by heat.

Check diode mode to ground on big coils; compare with good board.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message:
Reflowed the area on both sides to see if any change, but the same. 
I get a drop pulse on  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>  when  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>  3.3V is triggered.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message:
Check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, at same time.
If present, some pulse must be detected on big coils too.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message: No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulse when  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is triggered

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message:
Then you have PCH related issue.
Check its basic power on and RTC signals.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V_S5G</SIGNAL> - 1V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5G</SIGNAL> - 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> - 3.08V
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.07V

Thanks for your help

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message: I was expecting <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> too.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> - 3.08V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> - 2.81V
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.32V
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.07V
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 3.41V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0.02A after replaced blown <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message:
All look good; probably bad PCH/CPU.
When found <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips with burnt hole, its internal die is melt.
Overvoltage can affect PCH in such case, because of direct USB connection.
